fâ€‹(xÂ¯T)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±âˆ—)ğ‘“subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±\displaystyle f(\bar{x}_{T})-f(\mathbf{x}_{*}) â‰¤Î¼2â€‹(1âˆ’12â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K)T+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹GÎ±â€‹Î»2âˆ’Î±+4Î¼â€‹[2â€‹G2â€‹Î±â€‹Î»âˆ’2â€‹(Î±âˆ’1)+2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹GÎ±â€‹Î»2âˆ’Î±]absentğœ‡2superscript112ğœ‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptğºğ›¼superscriptğœ†2ğ›¼4ğœ‡delimited-[]2superscriptğº2ğ›¼superscriptğœ†2ğ›¼12superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğºğ›¼superscriptğœ†2ğ›¼\displaystyle\leq\frac{\mu}{2}\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\mu\eta\eta_{L}K\right)^{T}+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}G^{\alpha}\lambda^{2-\alpha}+\frac{4}{\mu}[2G^{2\alpha}\lambda^{-2(\alpha-1)}+2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}G^{\alpha}\lambda^{2-\alpha}]
â‰¤Î¼2â€‹expâ¡(âˆ’12â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹T)+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹GÎ±â€‹Î»2âˆ’Î±+4Î¼â€‹[2â€‹G2â€‹Î±â€‹Î»âˆ’2â€‹(Î±âˆ’1)+2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹GÎ±â€‹Î»2âˆ’Î±].absentğœ‡212ğœ‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptğºğ›¼superscriptğœ†2ğ›¼4ğœ‡delimited-[]2superscriptğº2ğ›¼superscriptğœ†2ğ›¼12superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğºğ›¼superscriptğœ†2ğ›¼\displaystyle\leq\frac{\mu}{2}\exp{\left(-\frac{1}{2}\mu\eta\eta_{L}KT\right)}+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}G^{\alpha}\lambda^{2-\alpha}+\frac{4}{\mu}[2G^{2\alpha}\lambda^{-2(\alpha-1)}+2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}G^{\alpha}\lambda^{2-\alpha}].

Let Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K=2â€‹cÎ¼â€‹lnâ¡(T)mâ€‹Kâ€‹Tğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2ğ‘ğœ‡ğ‘‡ğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡\eta\eta_{L}K=\frac{2c}{\mu}\frac{\ln(T)}{mKT} (câ‰¥1ğ‘1c\geq 1 is a constant and Tâˆ’câˆ’2âˆ’2â€‹Î±Î±â‰¤(mâ€‹K)2âˆ’2â€‹Î±Î±superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘22ğ›¼ğ›¼superscriptğ‘šğ¾22ğ›¼ğ›¼T^{-c-\frac{2-2\alpha}{\alpha}}\leq(mK)^{\frac{2-2\alpha}{\alpha}}), Î»=(mâ€‹Kâ€‹T)1Î±ğœ†superscriptğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡1ğ›¼\lambda=(mKT)^{\frac{1}{\alpha}}, and Î·Lâ‰¤(mâ€‹T)âˆ’12â€‹Kâˆ’32subscriptğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğ‘šğ‘‡12superscriptğ¾32\eta_{L}\leq(mT)^{-\frac{1}{2}}K^{-\frac{3}{2}},

fâ€‹(xÂ¯T)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±âˆ—)ğ‘“subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±\displaystyle f(\bar{x}_{T})-f(\mathbf{x}_{*}) â‰¤1Tc+(mâ€‹Kâ€‹T)2âˆ’2â€‹Î±Î±â€‹lnâ¡(T)=ğ’ª~â€‹((mâ€‹Kâ€‹T)2âˆ’2â€‹Î±Î±).absent1superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘superscriptğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡22ğ›¼ğ›¼ğ‘‡~ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡22ğ›¼ğ›¼\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{T^{c}}+(mKT)^{\frac{2-2\alpha}{\alpha}}\ln(T)=\tilde{\mathcal{O}}((mKT)^{\frac{2-2\alpha}{\alpha}}).

âˆ

See 4

Proof.

Due to the smoothness in Assumption 1, taking expectation of fâ€‹(ğ±t+1)ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡1f(\mathbf{x}_{t+1}) over the randomness at communication round tğ‘¡t, we have:

ğ”¼[f(ğ±t+1)]âˆ’f(ğ±t)â‰¤<âˆ‡f(ğ±t),ğ”¼[ğ±t+1âˆ’ğ±t]>+L2ğ”¼[âˆ¥ğ±t+1âˆ’ğ±tâˆ¥2]\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[f(\mathbf{x}_{t+1})]-f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\leq\big{<}\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t}),\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{x}_{t+1}-\mathbf{x}_{t}]\big{>}+\frac{L}{2}\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbf{x}_{t+1}-\mathbf{x}_{t}\|^{2}]
=âˆ’Î·â€‹Î·L<âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t),ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]>+L2â€‹Î·2â€‹Î·L2â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Î”~tâ€–2]formulae-sequenceabsentğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿âˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ¿2superscriptğœ‚2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript~Î”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle=-\eta\eta_{L}\big{<}\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t}),\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\big{>}+\frac{L}{2}\eta^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}\mathbb{E}[\|\tilde{\Delta}_{t}\|^{2}]
=âˆ’Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2âˆ’Î·â€‹Î·L2â€‹Kâ€‹â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)âˆ’1Kâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2+Lâ€‹Î·2â€‹Î·L22â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Î”~tâ€–2]absentğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿2ğ¾superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2ğ¿superscriptğœ‚2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿22ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript~Î”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle=-\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\|^{2}-\frac{\eta\eta_{L}}{2K}\|\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2}+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})-\frac{1}{K}\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2}+\frac{L\eta^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}}{2}\mathbb{E}[\|\tilde{\Delta}_{t}\|^{2}]
=âˆ’Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2+(âˆ’Î·â€‹Î·L2â€‹K+Lâ€‹Î·2â€‹Î·L22)â€‹â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)âˆ’1Kâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2+Lâ€‹Î·2â€‹Î·L22â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Î”~tâˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2]absentğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿2ğ¾ğ¿superscriptğœ‚2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿22superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2ğ¿superscriptğœ‚2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿22ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle=-\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\|^{2}+\left(-\frac{\eta\eta_{L}}{2K}+\frac{L\eta^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}}{2}\right)\|\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2}+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})-\frac{1}{K}\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2}+\frac{L\eta^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}}{2}\mathbb{E}[\|\tilde{\Delta}_{t}-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2}]
â‰¤âˆ’Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)âˆ’1Kâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2âŸA1+Lâ€‹Î·2â€‹Î·L22â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Î”~tâˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2]âŸA2,absentğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2subscriptâŸsuperscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2subscriptğ´1ğ¿superscriptğœ‚2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿22subscriptâŸğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2subscriptğ´2\displaystyle\leq-\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\|^{2}+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}\underbrace{\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})-\frac{1}{K}\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2}}_{A_{1}}+\frac{L\eta^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}}{2}\underbrace{\mathbb{E}[\|\tilde{\Delta}_{t}-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2}]}_{A_{2}}, (6)

where the last inequality follows from (âˆ’Î·â€‹Î·L2â€‹K+Lâ€‹Î·2â€‹Î·L22)â‰¤0ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿2ğ¾ğ¿superscriptğœ‚2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿220\left(-\frac{\eta\eta_{L}}{2K}+\frac{L\eta^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}}{2}\right)\leq 0 if Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹Lâ‰¤1ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾ğ¿1\eta\eta_{L}KL\leq 1.

From LemmaÂ 2, we have the bound of A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} and A2subscriptğ´2A_{2} in (6). By rearranging and telescoping, we have:

1Tâ€‹âˆ‘tâˆˆ[T]ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2â‰¤2â€‹(fâ€‹(ğ±1)âˆ’fâ€‹(xT))Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹T+(2â€‹G2â€‹Î±â€‹Î»âˆ’2â€‹(Î±âˆ’1)+2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹GÎ±â€‹Î»2âˆ’Î±)+Lâ€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lmâ€‹(GÎ±â€‹Î»2âˆ’Î±).1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡22ğ‘“subscriptğ±1ğ‘“subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡2superscriptğº2ğ›¼superscriptğœ†2ğ›¼12superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğºğ›¼superscriptğœ†2ğ›¼ğ¿ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ‘šsuperscriptğºğ›¼superscriptğœ†2ğ›¼\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t\in[T]}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\|^{2}\leq\frac{2\left(f(\mathbf{x}_{1})-f(x_{T})\right)}{\eta\eta_{L}KT}+\left(2G^{2\alpha}\lambda^{-2(\alpha-1)}+2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}G^{\alpha}\lambda^{2-\alpha}\right)+\frac{L\eta\eta_{L}}{m}\left(G^{\alpha}\lambda^{2-\alpha}\right).

Suppose Î·â€‹Î·L=m2â€‹Î±âˆ’23â€‹Î±âˆ’2â€‹(Kâ€‹T)âˆ’Î±3â€‹Î±âˆ’2,Î·Lâ‰¤(mâ€‹Kâ€‹T)âˆ’Î±6â€‹Î±âˆ’4formulae-sequenceğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğ‘š2ğ›¼23ğ›¼2superscriptğ¾ğ‘‡ğ›¼3ğ›¼2subscriptğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡ğ›¼6ğ›¼4\eta\eta_{L}=m^{\frac{2\alpha-2}{3\alpha-2}}(KT)^{\frac{-\alpha}{3\alpha-2}},\eta_{L}\leq(mKT)^{\frac{-\alpha}{6\alpha-4}}, and Î»=(mâ€‹Kâ€‹T)13â€‹Î±âˆ’2ğœ†superscriptğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡13ğ›¼2\lambda=(mKT)^{\frac{1}{3\alpha-2}},

mintâˆˆ[T]â¡ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹((mâ€‹Kâ€‹T)2âˆ’2â€‹Î±3â€‹Î±âˆ’2).subscriptğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡22ğ›¼3ğ›¼2\displaystyle\min_{t\in[T]}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\|^{2}\leq\mathcal{O}((mKT)^{\frac{2-2\alpha}{3\alpha-2}}).

âˆ

A.3 Proof of ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–±ğ–¯ğ–±\mathsf{PR}~{}in Gaussian Noise

In this subsection, we utilize the classic bounded variance and bounded gradient assumption.

Assumption 4.

(Bounded Stochastic Gradient Variance) There exists a constant Ïƒ>0ğœ0\sigma>0, such that the variance of each local gradient estimator is bounded by ğ”¼[âˆ¥âˆ‡fi(ğ±,Î¾)âˆ’âˆ‡fi(ğ±)||2]â‰¤Ïƒ2\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x},\xi)-\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x})||^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2}, âˆ€iâˆˆ[m]for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘š\forall i\in[m].

Assumption 5.

(Bounded Gradient ) There exists a constant Gâ‰¥0ğº0G\geq 0, such that gradient is bounded by âˆ¥âˆ‡fi(ğ±)||2â‰¤G2\|\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x})||^{2}\leq G^{2}, âˆ€iâˆˆ[m]for-allğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘š\forall i\in[m].

Lemma 3 (Lemma F.5Â [18]).

Suppose there exists a constant Ïƒğœ\sigma such that the variance of the stochastic gradient of Fğ¹F has bounded variance, i.e., ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ±,Î¾)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ±)â€–2]â‰¤Ïƒ2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹ğ±ğœ‰âˆ‡ğ¹ğ±2superscriptğœ2\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla F(\mathbf{x},\xi)-\nabla F(\mathbf{x})\|^{2}]\leq\sigma^{2}, and â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ±)â€–2â‰¤Î»2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ¹ğ±2ğœ†2\|\nabla F(\mathbf{x})\|^{2}\leq\frac{\lambda}{2}, then we have the following inequalities for the clipping âˆ‡~â€‹Fâ€‹(ğ±t)=ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡~â€‹Fâ€‹(ğ±,Î¾)]=ğ”¼â€‹[minâ¡{1,Î»â€–âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ±,Î¾)â€–}â€‹âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ±,Î¾)]~âˆ‡ğ¹subscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]~âˆ‡ğ¹ğ±ğœ‰ğ”¼delimited-[]1ğœ†normâˆ‡ğ¹ğ±ğœ‰âˆ‡ğ¹ğ±ğœ‰\tilde{\nabla}F(\mathbf{x}_{t})=\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\nabla}F(\mathbf{x},\xi)]=\mathbb{E}[\min\{1,\frac{\lambda}{\|\nabla F(\mathbf{x},\xi)\|}\}\nabla F(\mathbf{x},\xi)]:

â€–ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡~â€‹Fâ€‹(ğ±,Î¾)]âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ±)â€–2â‰¤16â€‹Ïƒ4Î»2,superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]~âˆ‡ğ¹ğ±ğœ‰âˆ‡ğ¹ğ±216superscriptğœ4superscriptğœ†2\displaystyle\|\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\nabla}F(\mathbf{x},\xi)]-\nabla F(\mathbf{x})\|^{2}\leq\frac{16\sigma^{4}}{\lambda^{2}},
ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡~â€‹Fâ€‹(ğ±,Î¾)âˆ’âˆ‡Fâ€‹(ğ±)â€–2â‰¤18â€‹Ïƒ2,ğ”¼superscriptnorm~âˆ‡ğ¹ğ±ğœ‰âˆ‡ğ¹ğ±218superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\tilde{\nabla}F(\mathbf{x},\xi)-\nabla F(\mathbf{x})\|^{2}\leq 18\sigma^{2},
ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡~â€‹Fâ€‹(ğ±,Î¾)âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡~â€‹Fâ€‹(ğ±,Î¾)]â€–2â‰¤18â€‹Ïƒ2.ğ”¼superscriptnorm~âˆ‡ğ¹ğ±ğœ‰ğ”¼delimited-[]~âˆ‡ğ¹ğ±ğœ‰218superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\tilde{\nabla}F(\mathbf{x},\xi)-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\nabla}F(\mathbf{x},\xi)]\|^{2}\leq 18\sigma^{2}.

We remark that for any stochastic estimator satisfies the above conditions, the above inequalities hold. The proof is the exactly same as that in original proofÂ [18].

Lemma 4 (Bounded Variance of Clipping Stochastic Local Updates in ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–±ğ–¯ğ–±\mathsf{PR}).

Assume fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i} satisfies the bounded variance assumption, then we have:

ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Î”t,iâˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”t,i]â€–2]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\|\Delta_{t,i}-\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{t,i}]\|^{2}] â‰¤Kâ€‹Ïƒ2.absentğ¾superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\leq K\sigma^{2}.

In addition, assume there exists a constant GğºG such that gradient is bounded â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±)â€–2â‰¤G2superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±2superscriptğº2\|\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x})\|^{2}\leq G^{2}, if we set clipping parameter as Î»2â‰¥2â€‹K2â€‹G2superscriptğœ†22superscriptğ¾2superscriptğº2\lambda^{2}\geq 2K^{2}G^{2}, i.e., â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±)â€–â‰¤Î»2normâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ±ğœ†2\|\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x})\|\leq\frac{\lambda}{2}, then we have:

â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Î”t,i]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t,i]â€–2superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\displaystyle\left\|\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{t,i}]-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t,i}]\right\|^{2} â‰¤16â€‹Kâ€‹Ïƒ4Î»2,absent16ğ¾superscriptğœ4superscriptğœ†2\displaystyle\leq\frac{16K\sigma^{4}}{\lambda^{2}},
ğ”¼â€‹â€–Î”~tâˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2ğ”¼superscriptnormsubscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\tilde{\Delta}_{t}-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2} â‰¤18â€‹Kmâ€‹Ïƒ4.absent18ğ¾ğ‘šsuperscriptğœ4\displaystyle\leq\frac{18K}{m}\sigma^{4}.

.

Proof.
ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Î”t,iâˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”t,i]â€–2]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[\|\Delta_{t,i}-\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{t,i}]\|^{2}] =ğ”¼â€‹[â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t,ij,Î¾t,ij)âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t,ij)]â€–2]absentğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘—ğ”¼delimited-[]âˆ‡ğ‘“superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘—2\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}[\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t,i}^{j},\xi_{t,i}^{j})-\mathbb{E}[\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t,i}^{j})]\|^{2}]
â‰¤Kâ€‹Ïƒ2,absentğ¾superscriptğœ2\displaystyle\leq K\sigma^{2},

where {âˆ‡f(ğ±t,ij,Î¾t,ij)âˆ’ğ”¼[âˆ‡f(ğ±t,ij)}\{\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t,i}^{j},\xi_{t,i}^{j})-\mathbb{E}[\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t,i}^{j})\} forms martingale difference sequence (Lemma 4 in Â [3]).

Then by applying LemmaÂ 3, we have the bound of â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Î”t,i]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t,i]â€–2superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\left\|\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{t,i}]-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t,i}]\right\|^{2}.

ğ”¼â€‹â€–Î”~tâˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2ğ”¼superscriptnormsubscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\|\tilde{\Delta}_{t}-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2} =ğ”¼â€‹â€–1mâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[m]Î”~t,iâˆ’1mâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[m]ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t,i]â€–2absentğ”¼superscriptnorm1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘šsubscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–1ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘šğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\displaystyle=\mathbb{E}\left\|\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}\tilde{\Delta}_{t,i}-\frac{1}{m}\sum_{i\in[m]}\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t,i}]\right\|^{2}
â‰¤18â€‹Kmâ€‹Ïƒ4.absent18ğ¾ğ‘šsuperscriptğœ4\displaystyle\leq\frac{18K}{m}\sigma^{4}.

where the last inequality follows from the fact that ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Î”t,iâˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”t,i]â€–2]â‰¤Kâ€‹Ïƒ2ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–2ğ¾superscriptğœ2\mathbb{E}[\|\Delta_{t,i}-\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{t,i}]\|^{2}]\leq K\sigma^{2}, {Î”t,iâˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”t,i]}subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–\{\Delta_{t,i}-\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{t,i}]\} forms martingale difference sequence and LemmaÂ 3. âˆ

Theorem 5.

Suppose fğ‘“f is non-convex function, under AssumptionsÂ 1, Â 2, Â 4, and Â 5, if Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹Lâ‰¤1ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾ğ¿1\eta\eta_{L}KL\leq 1, then the sequence of outputs {ğ±k}subscriptğ±ğ‘˜\{\mathbf{x}_{k}\} generated by Algorithm ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–±ğ–¯ğ–±\mathsf{PR}~{}satisfies:

1Tâ€‹âˆ‘tâˆˆ[T]ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–21ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t\in[T]}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\|^{2} â‰¤2â€‹(fâ€‹(ğ±0)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±T))Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹T+1Tâ€‹âˆ‘tâˆˆ[T](2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹(Ïƒ2+G2)+32â€‹Ïƒ4K2â€‹Î»t2)+(18â€‹Lâ€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lmâ€‹Ïƒ2).absent2ğ‘“subscriptğ±0ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğœ2superscriptğº232superscriptğœ4superscriptğ¾2superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘¡218ğ¿ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ‘šsuperscriptğœ2\displaystyle\leq\frac{2\left(f(\mathbf{x}_{0})-f(\mathbf{x}_{T})\right)}{\eta\eta_{L}KT}+\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t\in[T]}\left(2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}(\sigma^{2}+G^{2})+\frac{32\sigma^{4}}{K^{2}\lambda_{t}^{2}}\right)+\left(\frac{18L\eta\eta_{L}}{m}\sigma^{2}\right).

Choosing learning rates and clipping parameter as Î·â€‹Î·L=m1/2(Kâ€‹T)1/2,Î·Lâ‰¤1(mâ€‹T)1/2â€‹K5/2formulae-sequenceğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğ‘š12superscriptğ¾ğ‘‡12subscriptğœ‚ğ¿1superscriptğ‘šğ‘‡12superscriptğ¾52\eta\eta_{L}=\frac{m^{1/2}}{(KT)^{1/2}},\eta_{L}\leq\frac{1}{(mT)^{1/2}K^{5/2}}, and Î»tâ‰¥(mâ€‹T)1/4â€‹Kâˆ’3/4subscriptğœ†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘šğ‘‡14superscriptğ¾34\lambda_{t}\geq(mT)^{1/4}K^{-3/4},

mintâˆˆ[T]â¡ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹((mâ€‹Kâ€‹T)âˆ’12).subscriptğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡12\displaystyle\min_{t\in[T]}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\|^{2}\leq\mathcal{O}((mKT)^{-\frac{1}{2}}).
Proof.

Due to the smoothness in Assumption 1, taking expectation of fâ€‹(ğ±t+1)ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡1f(\mathbf{x}_{t+1}) over the randomness at communication round tğ‘¡t, we have the same inequality:

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ±t+1)]âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±t)â‰¤âˆ’Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)âˆ’1Kâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2âŸA1+Lâ€‹Î·2â€‹Î·L22â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Î”~tâˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2]âŸA2,ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡1ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2subscriptâŸsuperscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2subscriptğ´1ğ¿superscriptğœ‚2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿22subscriptâŸğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2subscriptğ´2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[f(\mathbf{x}_{t+1})]-f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\leq-\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\|^{2}+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}\underbrace{\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})-\frac{1}{K}\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2}}_{A_{1}}+\frac{L\eta^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}}{2}\underbrace{\mathbb{E}[\|\tilde{\Delta}_{t}-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2}]}_{A_{2}}, (7)

where it requires Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹Lâ‰¤1ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾ğ¿1\eta\eta_{L}KL\leq 1.

Note that the term A1subscriptğ´1A_{1} in (7) can be bounded as follows:

A1subscriptğ´1\displaystyle A_{1} =â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)âˆ’1Kâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2absentsuperscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle=\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})-\frac{1}{K}\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2}
=2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)âˆ’1Kâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[Î”t]â€–2+2K2â€‹â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Î”t]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2absent2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡22superscriptğ¾2superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle=2\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})-\frac{1}{K}\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{t}]\right\|^{2}+\frac{2}{K^{2}}\left\|\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{t}]-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\right\|^{2}
â‰¤2mâ€‹Kâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[m]âˆ‘kâˆˆ[K]â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±t)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±t,ik)â€–2+2mâ€‹K2â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[m]â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Î”t,i]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t,i]â€–2absent2ğ‘šğ¾subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘˜22ğ‘šsuperscriptğ¾2subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘šsuperscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\displaystyle\leq\frac{2}{mK}\sum_{i\in[m]}\sum_{k\in[K]}\left\|\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{t})-\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{t,i}^{k})\right\|^{2}+\frac{2}{mK^{2}}\sum_{i\in[m]}\left\|\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{t,i}]-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t,i}]\right\|^{2}
â‰¤2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2mâ€‹Kâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[m]âˆ‘kâˆˆ[K]ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‘jâˆˆ[k]âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±t,ij,Î¾t,ij)â€–2+2mâ€‹K2â€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[m]â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Î”t,i]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t,i]â€–2absent2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2ğ‘šğ¾subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾ğ”¼superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘—22ğ‘šsuperscriptğ¾2subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘šsuperscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\displaystyle\leq\frac{2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}}{mK}\sum_{i\in[m]}\sum_{k\in[K]}\mathbb{E}\left\|\sum_{j\in[k]}\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{t,i}^{j},\xi_{t,i}^{j})\right\|^{2}+\frac{2}{mK^{2}}\sum_{i\in[m]}\left\|\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{t,i}]-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t,i}]\right\|^{2}
â‰¤2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹(ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±t,ik,Î¾t,ik)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±t,ik)â€–2+â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±t,ik)â€–2)+32â€‹Ïƒ4K2â€‹Î»t2absent2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘˜2superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘˜232superscriptğœ4superscriptğ¾2superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\leq 2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}\left(\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{t,i}^{k},\xi_{t,i}^{k})-\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{t,i}^{k})\right\|^{2}+\left\|\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{t,i}^{k})\right\|^{2}\right)+\frac{32\sigma^{4}}{K^{2}\lambda_{t}^{2}}
â‰¤2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹(Ïƒ2+G2)+32â€‹Ïƒ4K2â€‹Î»t2absent2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğœ2superscriptğº232superscriptğœ4superscriptğ¾2superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\leq 2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}(\sigma^{2}+G^{2})+\frac{32\sigma^{4}}{K^{2}\lambda_{t}^{2}}

where the second inequality is due to smoothness assumptionÂ 1, the third inequality is due to LemmaÂ 4, and the last inequality follows from bounded variance assumptionÂ 4 and bounded gradient assumptionÂ 5.

From LemmaÂ 4, the term A2subscriptğ´2A_{2} in (7) can be bounded as follows:

A2subscriptğ´2\displaystyle A_{2} â‰¤18â€‹Kâ€‹Ïƒ2m.absent18ğ¾superscriptğœ2ğ‘š\displaystyle\leq\frac{18K\sigma^{2}}{m}.

Putting pieces together, we can have the one communication round descent in expectation:

ğ”¼â€‹[fâ€‹(ğ±t+1)]âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±t)â‰¤âˆ’Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)âˆ’1Kâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2âŸA1+Lâ€‹Î·2â€‹Î·L22â€‹ğ”¼â€‹[â€–Î”~tâˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2]âŸA2ğ”¼delimited-[]ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡1ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2subscriptâŸsuperscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2subscriptğ´1ğ¿superscriptğœ‚2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿22subscriptâŸğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2subscriptğ´2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}[f(\mathbf{x}_{t+1})]-f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\leq-\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\|^{2}+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}\underbrace{\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})-\frac{1}{K}\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2}}_{A_{1}}+\frac{L\eta^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}}{2}\underbrace{\mathbb{E}[\|\tilde{\Delta}_{t}-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\|^{2}]}_{A_{2}}
â‰¤âˆ’Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹(2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹(Ïƒ2+G2)+32â€‹Ïƒ4K2â€‹Î»t2)+18â€‹Lâ€‹Kâ€‹Î·2â€‹Î·L22â€‹mâ€‹Ïƒ2.absentğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾22superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğœ2superscriptğº232superscriptğœ4superscriptğ¾2superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘¡218ğ¿ğ¾superscriptğœ‚2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿22ğ‘šsuperscriptğœ2\displaystyle\leq-\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\|^{2}+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}\left(2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}(\sigma^{2}+G^{2})+\frac{32\sigma^{4}}{K^{2}\lambda_{t}^{2}}\right)+\frac{18LK\eta^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}}{2m}\sigma^{2}.

Rearranging and telescoping, we have the final convergence result:

1Tâ€‹âˆ‘tâˆˆ[T]ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–21ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t\in[T]}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\|^{2} â‰¤2â€‹(fâ€‹(ğ±0)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±T))Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹T+1Tâ€‹âˆ‘tâˆˆ[T](2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹(Ïƒ2+G2)+32â€‹Ïƒ2K2â€‹Î»t2)+(18â€‹Lâ€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lmâ€‹Ïƒ2).absent2ğ‘“subscriptğ±0ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡1ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğœ2superscriptğº232superscriptğœ2superscriptğ¾2superscriptsubscriptğœ†ğ‘¡218ğ¿ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ‘šsuperscriptğœ2\displaystyle\leq\frac{2\left(f(\mathbf{x}_{0})-f(\mathbf{x}_{T})\right)}{\eta\eta_{L}KT}+\frac{1}{T}\sum_{t\in[T]}\left(2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}(\sigma^{2}+G^{2})+\frac{32\sigma^{2}}{K^{2}\lambda_{t}^{2}}\right)+\left(\frac{18L\eta\eta_{L}}{m}\sigma^{2}\right).

Suppose Î·â€‹Î·L=m1/2(Kâ€‹T)1/2,Î·Lâ‰¤1(mâ€‹T)1/2â€‹K5/2formulae-sequenceğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğ‘š12superscriptğ¾ğ‘‡12subscriptğœ‚ğ¿1superscriptğ‘šğ‘‡12superscriptğ¾52\eta\eta_{L}=\frac{m^{1/2}}{(KT)^{1/2}},\eta_{L}\leq\frac{1}{(mT)^{1/2}K^{5/2}}, and Î»tâ‰¥(mâ€‹T)1/4â€‹Kâˆ’3/4subscriptğœ†ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘šğ‘‡14superscriptğ¾34\lambda_{t}\geq(mT)^{1/4}K^{-3/4},

mintâˆˆ[T]â¡ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)â€–2â‰¤ğ’ªâ€‹((mâ€‹Kâ€‹T)âˆ’12).subscriptğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡2ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡12\displaystyle\min_{t\in[T]}\mathbb{E}\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\|^{2}\leq\mathcal{O}((mKT)^{-\frac{1}{2}}).

âˆ

Theorem 6.

Suppose f is Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex function, under AssumptionsÂ 1â€“3, if Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ‰¥2Î¼â€‹Tğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2ğœ‡ğ‘‡\eta\eta_{L}K\geq\frac{2}{\mu T}, then the outputs ğ±Â¯TsubscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘‡\bar{\mathbf{x}}_{T} in Algorithm 2 (ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–±ğ–¯ğ–±\mathsf{PR}) by ğ±Â¯T=ğ±tsubscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘‡subscriptğ±ğ‘¡\bar{\mathbf{x}}_{T}=\mathbf{x}_{t} with probability wtâˆ‘jâˆˆ[T]wjsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—\frac{w_{t}}{\sum_{j\in[T]}w_{j}} where wt=(1âˆ’12â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K)1âˆ’tsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡superscript112ğœ‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾1ğ‘¡w_{t}=(1-\frac{1}{2}\mu\eta\eta_{L}K)^{1-t} satisfies:

fâ€‹(xÂ¯T)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±âˆ—)ğ‘“subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±\displaystyle f(\bar{x}_{T})-f(\mathbf{x}_{*}) â‰¤Î¼2â€‹expâ¡(âˆ’12â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹T)+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹G2+4Î¼â€‹[2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹(G2+Ïƒ2)+32â€‹Ïƒ4Î»2].absentğœ‡212ğœ‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptğº24ğœ‡delimited-[]2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğº2superscriptğœ232superscriptğœ4superscriptğœ†2\displaystyle\leq\frac{\mu}{2}\exp{\left(-\frac{1}{2}\mu\eta\eta_{L}KT\right)}+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}G^{2}+\frac{4}{\mu}[2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}(G^{2}+\sigma^{2})+\frac{32\sigma^{4}}{\lambda^{2}}].

Suppose Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K=2â€‹cÎ¼â€‹lnâ¡(T)mâ€‹Kâ€‹Tğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2ğ‘ğœ‡ğ‘‡ğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡\eta\eta_{L}K=\frac{2c}{\mu}\frac{\ln(T)}{mKT} (c>0ğ‘0c>0 is a constant and Tâˆ’c+1â‰¤(mâ€‹K)âˆ’1superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘1superscriptğ‘šğ¾1T^{-c+1}\leq(mK)^{-1}), Î»â‰¥(mâ€‹Kâ€‹T)12ğœ†superscriptğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡12\lambda\geq(mKT)^{\frac{1}{2}}, and Î·Lâ‰¤(mâ€‹T)âˆ’12â€‹Kâˆ’32subscriptğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğ‘šğ‘‡12superscriptğ¾32\eta_{L}\leq(mT)^{-\frac{1}{2}}K^{-\frac{3}{2}},

fâ€‹(xÂ¯T)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±âˆ—)ğ‘“subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±\displaystyle f(\bar{x}_{T})-f(\mathbf{x}_{*}) =ğ’ª~â€‹((mâ€‹Kâ€‹T)âˆ’1).absent~ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡1\displaystyle=\tilde{\mathcal{O}}((mKT)^{-1}).
Proof.
â€–1Kâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(x)â€–2â‰¤2â€‹â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ±t)âˆ’1Kâ€‹ğ”¼â€‹[Î”t]â€–2+2Kâ€‹â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Î”t]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t]â€–2superscriptnorm1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ‘¥22superscriptnormâˆ‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡1ğ¾ğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡22ğ¾superscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡2\displaystyle\|\frac{1}{K}\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]-\nabla f(x)\|^{2}\leq 2\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})-\frac{1}{K}\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{t}]\right\|^{2}+\frac{2}{K}\left\|\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{t}]-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t}]\right\|^{2}
â‰¤2mâ€‹Kâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[m]âˆ‘kâˆˆ[K]ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±t)âˆ’âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±t,ik)â€–2+2mâ€‹Kâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[m]â€–ğ”¼â€‹[Î”t,i]âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[Î”~t,i]â€–2absent2ğ‘šğ¾subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾ğ”¼superscriptnormâˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–subscriptğ±ğ‘¡âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘˜22ğ‘šğ¾subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘šsuperscriptnormğ”¼delimited-[]subscriptÎ”ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ”¼delimited-[]subscript~Î”ğ‘¡ğ‘–2\displaystyle\leq\frac{2}{mK}\sum_{i\in[m]}\sum_{k\in[K]}\mathbb{E}\left\|\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{t})-\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{t,i}^{k})\right\|^{2}+\frac{2}{mK}\sum_{i\in[m]}\left\|\mathbb{E}[\Delta_{t,i}]-\mathbb{E}[\tilde{\Delta}_{t,i}]\right\|^{2}
â‰¤2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2mâ€‹Kâ€‹âˆ‘iâˆˆ[m]âˆ‘kâˆˆ[K]ğ”¼â€‹â€–âˆ‘jâˆˆ[k]âˆ‡fiâ€‹(ğ±t,ij,Î¾t,ij)â€–2+32â€‹Ïƒ4Î»2absent2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2ğ‘šğ¾subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾ğ”¼superscriptnormsubscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘˜âˆ‡subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘—superscriptsubscriptğœ‰ğ‘¡ğ‘–ğ‘—232superscriptğœ4superscriptğœ†2\displaystyle\leq\frac{2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}}{mK}\sum_{i\in[m]}\sum_{k\in[K]}\mathbb{E}\left\|\sum_{j\in[k]}\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{x}_{t,i}^{j},\xi_{t,i}^{j})\right\|^{2}+\frac{32\sigma^{4}}{\lambda^{2}}
â‰¤2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹(G2+Ïƒ2)+32â€‹Ïƒ4Î»2.absent2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğº2superscriptğœ232superscriptğœ4superscriptğœ†2\displaystyle\leq 2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}(G^{2}+\sigma^{2})+\frac{32\sigma^{4}}{\lambda^{2}}.

Similarly, we have

fâ€‹(ğ±t)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±âˆ—)ğ‘“subscriptğ±ğ‘¡ğ‘“subscriptğ±\displaystyle f(\mathbf{x}_{t})-f(\mathbf{x}_{*}) â‰¤12â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹[âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ±t+1âˆ’xâˆ—â€–2]+(1âˆ’12â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K)â€‹â€–ğ±tâˆ’xâˆ—â€–2]absent12ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾delimited-[]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¥2112ğœ‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾superscriptnormsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥2\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{2\eta\eta_{L}K}\left[-\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbf{x}_{t+1}-x_{*}\|^{2}]+(1-\frac{1}{2}\mu\eta\eta_{L}K)\|\mathbf{x}_{t}-x_{*}\|^{2}\right]
+Î·â€‹Î·L2â€‹Kğ”¼[âˆ¥Î”~tâˆ¥2]+4Î¼âˆ¥ğ”¼[1KÎ”~tâˆ’âˆ‡f(ğ±t)âˆ¥2\displaystyle\quad+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}}{2K}\mathbb{E}[\|\tilde{\Delta}_{t}\|^{2}]+\frac{4}{\mu}\|\mathbb{E}[\frac{1}{K}\tilde{\Delta}_{t}-\nabla f(\mathbf{x}_{t})\|^{2}
â‰¤12â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹[âˆ’ğ”¼â€‹[â€–ğ±t+1âˆ’xâˆ—â€–2]+(1âˆ’12â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K)â€‹â€–ğ±tâˆ’xâˆ—â€–2]absent12ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾delimited-[]ğ”¼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¥2112ğœ‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾superscriptnormsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥2\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{2\eta\eta_{L}K}\left[-\mathbb{E}[\|\mathbf{x}_{t+1}-x_{*}\|^{2}]+(1-\frac{1}{2}\mu\eta\eta_{L}K)\|\mathbf{x}_{t}-x_{*}\|^{2}\right]
+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹G2+4Î¼â€‹[2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹(G2+Ïƒ2)+32â€‹Ïƒ4Î»2],ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptğº24ğœ‡delimited-[]2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğº2superscriptğœ232superscriptğœ4superscriptğœ†2\displaystyle\quad+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}G^{2}+\frac{4}{\mu}[2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}(G^{2}+\sigma^{2})+\frac{32\sigma^{4}}{\lambda^{2}}],

Let wt=(1âˆ’12â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K)1âˆ’tsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡superscript112ğœ‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾1ğ‘¡w_{t}=(1-\frac{1}{2}\mu\eta\eta_{L}K)^{1-t}, ğ±Â¯T=ğ±tsubscriptÂ¯ğ±ğ‘‡subscriptğ±ğ‘¡\bar{\mathbf{x}}_{T}=\mathbf{x}_{t} with probability wtâˆ‘jâˆˆ[T]wjsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—\frac{w_{t}}{\sum_{j\in[T]}w_{j}}.

fâ€‹(xÂ¯T)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±âˆ—)ğ‘“subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±\displaystyle f(\bar{x}_{T})-f(\mathbf{x}_{*}) â‰¤1âˆ‘jâˆˆ[T]wjâ€‹âˆ‘tâˆˆ[T](wt2â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹[âˆ’â€–ğ±t+1âˆ’xâˆ—â€–2+(1âˆ’12â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K)â€‹â€–ğ±tâˆ’xâˆ—â€–2])absent1subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡1subscriptğ‘¥2112ğœ‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾superscriptnormsubscriptğ±ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¥2\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{\sum_{j\in[T]}w_{j}}\sum_{t\in[T]}\left(\frac{w_{t}}{2\eta\eta_{L}K}\left[-\|\mathbf{x}_{t+1}-x_{*}\|^{2}+(1-\frac{1}{2}\mu\eta\eta_{L}K)\|\mathbf{x}_{t}-x_{*}\|^{2}\right]\right)
+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹G2+4Î¼â€‹[2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹(G2+Ïƒ2)+32â€‹Ïƒ4Î»2]ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptğº24ğœ‡delimited-[]2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğº2superscriptğœ232superscriptğœ4superscriptğœ†2\displaystyle\quad+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}G^{2}+\frac{4}{\mu}[2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}(G^{2}+\sigma^{2})+\frac{32\sigma^{4}}{\lambda^{2}}]
â‰¤1âˆ‘jâˆˆ[T]wjâ€‹12â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹â€–ğ±1âˆ’xâˆ—â€–2+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹G2+4Î¼â€‹[2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹(G2+Ïƒ2)+32â€‹Ïƒ4Î»2].absent1subscriptğ‘—delimited-[]ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—12ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾superscriptnormsubscriptğ±1subscriptğ‘¥2ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptğº24ğœ‡delimited-[]2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğº2superscriptğœ232superscriptğœ4superscriptğœ†2\displaystyle\leq\frac{1}{\sum_{j\in[T]}w_{j}}\frac{1}{2\eta\eta_{L}K}\|\mathbf{x}_{1}-x_{*}\|^{2}+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}G^{2}+\frac{4}{\mu}[2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}(G^{2}+\sigma^{2})+\frac{32\sigma^{4}}{\lambda^{2}}].

Same as that in heavy-tailed noise case, we have the same bound for 2â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹âˆ‘tâˆˆ[T]wt2ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾subscriptğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡2\eta\eta_{L}K\sum_{t\in[T]}w_{t}:

2â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹âˆ‘tâˆˆ[T]wt2ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾subscriptğ‘¡delimited-[]ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘¡\displaystyle 2\eta\eta_{L}K\sum_{t\in[T]}w_{t} â‰¥2Î¼â€‹(1âˆ’12â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K)âˆ’T,absent2ğœ‡superscript112ğœ‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡\displaystyle\geq\frac{2}{\mu}\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\mu\eta\eta_{L}K\right)^{-T},

where it requires Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ‰¥2Î¼â€‹Tğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2ğœ‡ğ‘‡\eta\eta_{L}K\geq\frac{2}{\mu T}.

fâ€‹(xÂ¯T)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±âˆ—)ğ‘“subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±\displaystyle f(\bar{x}_{T})-f(\mathbf{x}_{*}) â‰¤Î¼2â€‹(1âˆ’12â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K)T+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹G2+4Î¼â€‹[2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹(G2+Ïƒ2)+32â€‹Ïƒ4Î»2]absentğœ‡2superscript112ğœ‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptğº24ğœ‡delimited-[]2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğº2superscriptğœ232superscriptğœ4superscriptğœ†2\displaystyle\leq\frac{\mu}{2}\left(1-\frac{1}{2}\mu\eta\eta_{L}K\right)^{T}+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}G^{2}+\frac{4}{\mu}[2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}(G^{2}+\sigma^{2})+\frac{32\sigma^{4}}{\lambda^{2}}]
â‰¤Î¼2â€‹expâ¡(âˆ’12â€‹Î¼â€‹Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹Kâ€‹T)+Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K2â€‹G2+4Î¼â€‹[2â€‹L2â€‹Î·L2â€‹K2â€‹(G2+Ïƒ2)+32â€‹Ïƒ4Î»2].absentğœ‡212ğœ‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾ğ‘‡ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2superscriptğº24ğœ‡delimited-[]2superscriptğ¿2superscriptsubscriptğœ‚ğ¿2superscriptğ¾2superscriptğº2superscriptğœ232superscriptğœ4superscriptğœ†2\displaystyle\leq\frac{\mu}{2}\exp{\left(-\frac{1}{2}\mu\eta\eta_{L}KT\right)}+\frac{\eta\eta_{L}K}{2}G^{2}+\frac{4}{\mu}[2L^{2}\eta_{L}^{2}K^{2}(G^{2}+\sigma^{2})+\frac{32\sigma^{4}}{\lambda^{2}}].

Let Î·â€‹Î·Lâ€‹K=2â€‹cÎ¼â€‹lnâ¡(T)mâ€‹Kâ€‹Tğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ¾2ğ‘ğœ‡ğ‘‡ğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡\eta\eta_{L}K=\frac{2c}{\mu}\frac{\ln(T)}{mKT} (c>0ğ‘0c>0 is a constant and Tâˆ’c+1â‰¤(mâ€‹K)âˆ’1superscriptğ‘‡ğ‘1superscriptğ‘šğ¾1T^{-c+1}\leq(mK)^{-1}), Î»â‰¥(mâ€‹Kâ€‹T)12ğœ†superscriptğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡12\lambda\geq(mKT)^{\frac{1}{2}}, and Î·Lâ‰¤(mâ€‹T)âˆ’12â€‹Kâˆ’32subscriptğœ‚ğ¿superscriptğ‘šğ‘‡12superscriptğ¾32\eta_{L}\leq(mT)^{-\frac{1}{2}}K^{-\frac{3}{2}},

fâ€‹(xÂ¯T)âˆ’fâ€‹(ğ±âˆ—)ğ‘“subscriptÂ¯ğ‘¥ğ‘‡ğ‘“subscriptğ±\displaystyle f(\bar{x}_{T})-f(\mathbf{x}_{*}) =ğ’ª~â€‹((mâ€‹Kâ€‹T)âˆ’1).absent~ğ’ªsuperscriptğ‘šğ¾ğ‘‡1\displaystyle=\tilde{\mathcal{O}}((mKT)^{-1}).

âˆ

Appendix B Experiments in SectionÂ 3

In this section, we provide experimental details to demonstrate the fat-tailed noise phenomenon in federated learning. We conduct experiments with CNN on CIFAR-10 dataset as shown in SectionÂ 3, and provide additional results of RNN model on Shakespeare dataset. Furthermore, we verify the accuracy of Î±ğ›¼\alpha estimation with logistic regression on MNIST dataset.

B.1 CNN on CIFAR-10 Dataset

B.1.1 Experiment details

We run a convolutional neural network (CNN) model on CIFAR-10 dataset using FedAvg. The CNN architecture is shown in TableÂ 2. To simulate data heterogeneity across clients, we manually distribute the the data to each client in a label-based partition. Specifically, we split the data according to the classes (pğ‘p) of images that each client has. Then, we randomly distribute these partitioned data to m=100ğ‘š100m=100 clients such that each client has only pğ‘p classes of images in both training and test data, which causes the heterogeneity of data among different clients. For example, for p=10ğ‘10p=10, each client contains training/test data samples with ten classes. Since CIFAR-10 has 101010 classes of images, p=10ğ‘10p=10 is the nearly i.i.d case. For the remaining pğ‘p, each client contains data samples with class pğ‘p. Therefore, the classes (pğ‘p) of images in each clientâ€™s local dataset can be used to represent the non-i.i.d. degree. The smaller the pğ‘p-value, the more heterogeneous the data between clients.

In this experimental setting, we use the global learning rate Î·â€‹Î·Lm=1.0ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ‘š1.0\frac{\eta\eta_{L}}{m}=1.0 and the local learning rate Î·L=0.1subscriptğœ‚ğ¿0.1\eta_{L}=0.1. The batch size is set to 500, and the communication round is T=4000ğ‘‡4000T=4000. We run this experiment in different cases, including singleSGD and different local epochs {1,2,5}125\left\{1,2,5\right\} and non-iid index pâˆˆ{1,2,5,10}ğ‘12510p\in\left\{1,2,5,10\right\}. Single SGD means one local update step, which is equivalent to mini-batch SGD.

B.1.2 Additional experimental results

We provide additional distributions of the norms of the pseudo-gradient noises in different cases as follows. From Fig.Â 7-Â 10, the observation is that the gradient norm statistics are contracted together for more iid cases while dispersed uniformly for more non-iid cases. This is

B.2 RNN on Shakespeare Dataset

B.2.1 Experiment details

To provide more evidences of the fat-tailed noise phenomenon, we further run a recurrent neural network (RNN) model on Shakespeare dataset.

Shakespeare dataset is a natural non-iid dataset, and it is built from The Complete Works of William ShakespeareÂ [1]. The learning task is to predict next character, and there are 80 classes of characters in total. We use a two-layer LSTM classifier containing 100 hidden units with an 8-dimensional (8D) embedding layer. The model inputs a sequence of 80 characters, embeds each of the characters into a learned 8D space, and then outputs one character per training sample after two LSTM layers and a densely-connected layer. The dataset and model are taken fromÂ [45].

There are m=143ğ‘š143m=143 clients participating in this experiment. The global learning rate is chosen as 1.01.01.0, and the local learning rate is chosen as 0.80.80.8. The batch size is set to 101010, and the communication round is T=150ğ‘‡150T=150.

B.2.2 Experimental results

We show the results when local step is set to be one (Single SGD), and multiple local epochs {1,2,5}125\{1,2,5\}. In Fig.Â 11, we observe that the Î±ğ›¼\alpha-value is smaller than 2, and it increases when the number of local epoch increases. This implies that the gradient noise is fat-tailed. Fig.Â 12 shows that the distributions of the norms of the pseudo-gradient noises are fat-tailed.

B.3 Accuracy of Alpha Estimation (Logistic Regression on MNIST Dataset)

Accurate Î±ğ›¼\alpha-value computation requires the full-gradient calculation, and we have to compute both full-gradient and stochastic gradient in each local step. This is computationally expensive. Instead, we use an estimation to approximate the exact Î±ğ›¼\alpha-value. The full-gradient is replaced by the mean value of the stochastic gradients. We verify the accuracy of this estimation method by running logistic regression on MNIST datasetÂ [46]. The details and the results are described as follows.

B.3.1 Experiment details

MNIST dataset contains ten classes of images, and it is manually partitioned using the same method as to partition CIFAR-10 dataset (see details in AppendixÂ B.1.1). The number of classes (pğ‘p) that each client has can be used to represent the non-iid level.

m=100ğ‘š100m=100 clients participate in the experiment. The communication round is T=150ğ‘‡150T=150. The global learning rate is set to 1.01.01.0, and the local learning rate is set to 0.10.10.1. The batch size is chosen to be 646464.

B.3.2 Experimental results

TableÂ 3 shows the error rate of Î±ğ›¼\alpha-value estimation in different cases, and this implies that the estimation of Î±ğ›¼\alpha-value is within an acceptable margin of error.

Appendix C Experiments in SectionÂ 5

In this section, we describe the details of the numerical experiments from SectionÂ 5 and provide some extra experimental results.

C.1 Experiment details

C.1.1 Strongly Convex Model with Synthetic Data

In these experiments, we consider a strongly convex model for ProblemÂ (1) as follows:

fiâ€‹(x)=ğ”¼Î¾â€‹[fiâ€‹(x,Î¾)]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥subscriptğ”¼ğœ‰delimited-[]subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğœ‰\displaystyle f_{i}\left(x\right)=\mathbb{E}_{\xi}\left[f_{i}\left(x,\xi\right)\right]
fiâ€‹(x,Î¾)=12â€‹â€–xâ€–2+âŸ¨Î¾,xâŸ©,subscriptğ‘“ğ‘–ğ‘¥ğœ‰12superscriptnormğ‘¥2ğœ‰ğ‘¥\displaystyle f_{i}\left(x,\xi\right)=\frac{1}{2}\left\|x\right\|^{2}+\left\langle\xi,x\right\rangle,

where xâˆˆâ„3Ã—1ğ‘¥superscriptâ„31x\in\mathbb{R}^{3\times 1} and Î¾ğœ‰\xi is a random vector. The optimal solution is fâ€‹(xâˆ—)=0ğ‘“superscriptğ‘¥0f\left(x^{*}\right)=0 with xâˆ—=[0;0;0]superscriptğ‘¥000x^{*}=\left[0;0;0\right].

To compare the performance of FedAvg, ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¨\mathsf{PI}~{}and ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–±ğ–¯ğ–±\mathsf{PR}~{}, we consider the noise Î¾ğœ‰\xi to be a Cauchy distribution(Î±<2ğ›¼2\alpha<2, fat-tailed) with a location parameter of 00 and a scale parameter of 2.12.12.1.

To compare the performance of ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¨\mathsf{PI}~{}and ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–±ğ–¯ğ–±\mathsf{PR}~{}under different scenarios, we consider the noise Î¾ğœ‰\xi having different tail-indexes (Î±=0.5,1.0,Â andÂ â€‹1.5ğ›¼0.51.0Â andÂ 1.5\alpha=0.5,1.0,\text{ and }1.5) with the same location parameters of 00 and the same scale parameters of 111.

For all the distributions of Î¾ğœ‰\xi mentioned above, we use the same experimental setup. There are m=5ğ‘š5m=5 clients participating in the training. We choose the starting point x0=[2;1;1.5]subscriptğ‘¥0211.5x_{0}=\left[2;1;1.5\right]. We set the global learning rate Î·â€‹Î·Lm=0.1ğœ‚subscriptğœ‚ğ¿ğ‘š0.1\frac{\eta\eta_{L}}{m}=0.1 and the local learning rate Î·L=0.1subscriptğœ‚ğ¿0.1\eta_{L}=0.1. The local steps we use is K=2ğ¾2K=2, and the communication round is T=300ğ‘‡300T=300. The clipping parameter in ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¨\mathsf{PI}~{}we select is Î»=3ğœ†3\lambda=3, and the clipping parameter in ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–±ğ–¯ğ–±\mathsf{PR}~{}is Î»=5ğœ†5\lambda=5.

C.1.2 CNN (Non-convex Model) on the CIFAR-10

To test the performance of ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¨\mathsf{PI}~{}and ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–±ğ–¯ğ–±\mathsf{PR}~{}for non-convex function, we run a convolutional neural network (CNN) on CIFAR-10 dataset. We compare ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¨\mathsf{PI}~{}and ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–±ğ–¯ğ–±\mathsf{PR}~{}with FedAvg under different data heterogeneity.

In this experimental setting, we randomly select five clients from m=10ğ‘š10m=10 clients to participate in each round of the training. The local epoch we use is two. The clipping parameter in ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¨\mathsf{PI}~{}we select is Î»=50ğœ†50\lambda=50, and the clipping parameter in ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–±ğ–¯ğ–±\mathsf{PR}~{}is Î»=2ğœ†2\lambda=2. All the remaining settings are the same as described in AppendixÂ B.1.1.

C.2 Additional experimental Results

We provide two additional results when applying FedAvg, ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¨\mathsf{PI}~{}and ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–±ğ–¯ğ–±\mathsf{PR}~{}to the CNN model on CIFAR-10 dataset. In Fig.Â 13, we show the percentage of successful training over 5 trials in non-i.i.d. cases when the non-i.i.d. index p=1ğ‘1p=1 and p=5ğ‘5p=5. These results further support our finding that ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}~{}methods and especially ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³ğ–¥ğ– ğ–³\mathsf{FAT}-ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€ğ–¢ğ—…ğ—‚ğ—‰ğ—‰ğ—‚ğ—‡ğ—€\mathsf{Clipping}-ğ–¯ğ–¨ğ–¯ğ–¨\mathsf{PI}~{}reduce catastrophic training failures compared to FedAvg.
